prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for breaking a couple by telling them what they really think of each other?
I'm on the debate team. My partner and I are planning to run for co-captains of policy next year (one type of debate). My partner, let's call him Tim, is honestly the better debater out of the two of us. But I'm a better writer, and more importantly in this case, better at politics (well, as much as a high schooler can be).

I anticipate our main competition is a team, which also happens to be a couple: James, and Mary. 

The main reason I worry about them is because they're from two different social groups, with different friends. Here's what I mean: my partner and I, we were friends before high school (and therefore debate) even started. Our friend group is the same. On the other hand, James and Mary come from two different 'cliques': James is popular in and out of debate, confident, and friends with all the more social, showy members of the team who joined because they love public speaking and all that. Mary is quiter, more intellectual and into philosophical stuff, and is friends with the more intellectual wing of the debate team. So a joint ticket with them has a chance to get votes from both groups. 

The thing is, while I'm not friends with either of them, I know from casually talking to them that neither of them are really happy with the relationship, but don't want to break up because they'll know it'll effect their debate partnership. Mary kind of sees James as 'big mouth, small brain'. James sees Mary as overly idealistic, anti social, and at times boring. 

So I told each of them what the other thought of them. This caused an argument in the middle of the debate meeting, and they actually broke up then and there. James was legit crying, and he blamed me for this. But everyone else seemed to agree that I was doing them a favor: they were incompatible but kept dating because of debate, and it made them unhappy.

So who's right? James or everybody else? Aita?


"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this scenario. The user is part of a debate team and is considering whether they did the right thing by breaking up a couple, James and Mary, because they knew the two had incompatible views and were unhappy. The user did this to help them both and maybe gain an advantage in the competition.

First, I need to think about the ethics here. Did the user have the right to intervene in their relationship? Relationships are personal, and even if the couple was unhappy, it's their decision to end it. The user's motivation was partly altruistic (helping them be happier) and partly strategic (to outcompete them in debate). But mixing personal relationships with competition can be tricky.

The user claims they told each person what the other thought. Where did they get this information? If they were just sharing their own perceptions without confirming the truth, that's one thing. If they were relaying what they overheard or were told by others, that's gossip. But the user says they know from casual talks, so maybe they have some basis. Still, even if true, is it okay to act as a matchmaker?

Consequences matter. The breakup caused an argument and James was crying. Even if the couple was unhappy, causing a public breakup might be harsh. The user might have crossed a line by taking it upon themselves to end the relationship, even if they thought it was for the best. Intentions are good, but the method could be questionable.

Then there's the debate competition aspect. The user is trying to position themselves and their partner as a better choice for co-captains. Using the breakup as a strategy to eliminate competition could be seen as underhanded. It might reflect poorly on their character if others perceive them as manipulative.

Others on the team agreed the user was doing a favor, which might suggest that some see the couple as a fake relationship. But that doesn't make it right. The user should have approached it differently, maybe suggesting they talk to each other instead of playing matchmaker.

So, in terms of right or wrong, the user's actions were meddling in a personal relationship with a mix of good intentions and self-interest. While the outcome might have been positive for the couple's happiness, the method of intervention could be seen as crossing a boundary. Therefore, the user might be in the wrong for taking that direct action without considering the personal boundaries and the potential harm caused.
